Officier of the [[Legion of Honour|LÃ©gion d'honneur]] }} '''Chesley Burnett''' "'''Sully'''" '''Sullenberger III''' (born 1951) is a retired American [[Pilot in command|airline captain]] who, on January 15, 2009, landed [[US Airways Flight 1549]] in the [[Hudson River]] off [[Manhattan]] after both engines were disabled by a [[bird strike]]; all 155 persons aboard survived. Sullenberger is a speaker on [[Aviation safety|airline safety]]{{cite news| title = US Airways captain the 'consummate pilot' |publisher = [[CNN]]| date =January 16, 2009 |url= http://edition.cnn.com/2009/US/01/16/crash.pilot.profile/| accessdate =January 16, 2009}} and has helped develop new protocols for airline safety. He served as the co-chairman, along with First Officer [[Jeffrey Skiles]], of the [[Experimental Aircraft Association|EAA]]'s [[Young Eagles]] youth introduction-to-aviation program from 2009 to 2013.{{cite web|url=http://generalaviationnews.com/2009/09/30/sullenberger-skiles-tapped-for-young-eagles/|title=Sullenberger, Skiles tapped for Young Eagles |publisher=General Aviation News|date=September 30, 2009|accessdate=August 29, 2016}} Sullenberger retired from US Airways after 30 years as a commercial pilot on March 3, 2010.Weiss, Mitch; Bomkamp, Samantha (March 3, 2010). [https://www.seattletimes.com/business/miracle-on-the-hudson-pilot-sullenberger-retires/ "'Miracle on the Hudson' pilot Sullenberger retires"]. ''[[The Seattle Times]]''. In May of the following year, Sullenberger was hired by [[CBS News]] as an Aviation and Safety Expert.[http://www.mediabistro.com/tvnewser/sully-sullenberger-named-cbs-news-aviation-and-safety-expert_b67331 "'Sully' Sullenberger named CBS News Aviation and Safety Expert"]. TV Newser, May 19, 2011 He is the co-author, with [[Jeffrey Zaslow]], of the [[The New York Times Best Seller list|''New York Times'' bestseller]] ''[[Highest Duty: My Search for What Really Matters]]'', a memoir of his life and of the events surrounding Flight 1549, published in 2009 by [[HarperCollins]]. His second book, ''Making a Difference: Stories of Vision and Courage from America's Leaders'', was published in May 2012. He was ranked second in ''[[Time (magazine)|Time]]''{{'}}s "[[Time 100|Top 100 Most Influential Heroes and Icons of 2009]]", after [[Michelle Obama]].{{cite web|url=http://www.time.com/time/specials/packages/article/0,28804,1894410_1894289_1894258,00.html|title=The 2009 TIME 100|author=General Chuck Yeager|publisher=[[Time Inc]]|date=April 30, 2009|accessdate=December 20, 2009}} ==Early life== Chesley Sullenberger was born in [[Denison, Texas]].[https://www.biography.com/people/chesley-sullenberger-20851353 "Chesley Sullenberger"]. [[Biography.com]]. Retrieved August 1, 2017. His father was a descendant of [[Swiss people|Swiss-German]] immigrants named Sollenberger.{{cite news|url=http://www.bernerzeitung.ch/region/emmental/Held-vom-Hudson-stammt-aus-Wynigen/story/11891131|title="Held vom Hudson" stammt aus Wynigen|date=January 20, 2009|work=[[Berner Zeitung]]|language=English|accessdate=January 20, 2009}} He has one sister, Mary. The street on which he grew up in Denison was named after his mother's family. According to his sister, Sullenberger built model planes and [[aircraft carrier]]s during his childhood, and says he became interested in flying after seeing military jets from an Air Force base near his house.{{cite news |first=Ray |last=Rivera |title=In a Split Second, a Pilot Becomes a Hero Years in the Making |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2009/01/17/nyregion/17pilot.html?hp |work=[[The New York Times]] |date=January 16, 2009 |accessdate=January 17, 2009}} He went to school in Denison, and was consistently on the 99th [[percentile]] in every academic category.{{cite web |title = Hero Pilot's Records, IQ Scores Released by School District in 'Accident' |publisher=[[Fox News]] |date = January 16, 2009 |url = http://www.foxnews.com/story/0,2933,480250,00.html| accessdate=January 16, 2009}} At the age of 12, his [[IQ]] was deemed [[Mensa International#Membership requirement|high enough]] to join [[Mensa International]]. In high school, he was the president of the [[Latin language|Latin]] club, a [[Wiktionary:first chair|first chair]] [[flutist]], and an [[honor student]]. He was an active member of the Waples Memorial [[United Methodist Church]] in Denison,{{cite web|last1=Lovelace|first1=John A.|title=United Methodist church nurtured hero pilot|url=http://archives.gcah.org/bitstream/handle/10516/345/6768959.htm|website=gcah.org|publisher=United Methodist News Service|accessdate=December 4, 2017|date=February 17, 2009}} and graduated from [[Denison High School]] in 1969,{{cite news | last= Longish | first= Dawn | title= 'Hero on the Hudson' Pilot grew up in North Texas | work= [[KDAF|The 33 News]] | location= Dallas/Fort Worth, TX | date= January 16, 2009 | url= http://www.the33tv.com/pages/content_landing_page/?Hero-on-the-Hudson-Pilot-grew-up-in-Nort=1&blockID=188187&feedID=460 | accessdate= January 18, 2009 | deadurl= yes | archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090122210550/http://www.the33tv.com/pages/content_landing_page/?Hero-on-the-Hudson-Pilot-grew-up-in-Nort=1&blockID=188187&feedID=460 | archivedate= January 22, 2009 | df= }} near the top of his class of about 350. At 16, Sullenberger learned to fly in an [[Aeronca Champion|Aeronca 7DC]] from a private airstrip near his home. He said the training he received from a local flight instructor influenced his aviation career for the rest of his life.{{cite news|title=Hero Pilot 'Sully' Sullenberger Tries To Stay Grounded|url=https://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=121345792|accessdate=December 2, 2017|work=[[NPR]]|date=December 11, 2009|language=en}} ===Education=== Sullenberger holds a [[Bachelor of Science]] from the [[United States Air Force Academy]]. He also holds a [[master's degree]] in [[Industrial Psychology]] from [[Purdue University]] and a master's degree in [[Public Administration]] from the [[University of Northern Colorado]]. ==Military service== [[File:Chesley Burnett Sullenberger III, USAFA'73.jpg|thumb|upright|Sullenberger's 1973 Air Force Academy senior class photo]] Sullenberger was appointed to the [[United States Air Force Academy]], entering with the Class of 1973 in June 1969. He was selected along with around a dozen other freshmen for a cadet [[Gliding|glider]] program, and by the end of that year, he was an instructor pilot. In the year of his graduation, 1973, he received the Outstanding Cadet in Airmanship award, as the class "top flyer". Following graduation with a [[Bachelor of Science]] and his commissioning as an officer, the Air Force immediately sent Sullenberger to [[Purdue University]] to pursue a master's degree prior to entering Undergraduate Pilot Training (UPT).{{cite web| title = Safety Reliability Methods, Inc.: About us| publisher = Safety Reliability Methods, Inc| year = 2007| url = http://safetyreliability.com/about_us| accessdate = January 16, 2009| deadurl = yes| archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20090118124522/http://safetyreliability.com/about_us| archivedate = January 18, 2009| df = }} Following completion of his graduate degree at Purdue, he was assigned to UPT at [[Columbus AFB]], Mississippi, flying the [[T-37 Tweet]] and [[T-38 Talon]]. After earning his wings in 1975 as a [[U.S. Air Force aeronautical rating|USAF Pilot]], he completed replacement training in the [[F-4 Phantom II]] at [[Luke AFB]], Arizona. This was followed by his assignment to the [[493d Fighter Squadron|493d Tactical Fighter Squadron]] of [[48th Fighter Wing|48th Tactical Fighter Wing]] at [[RAF Lakenheath]], United Kingdom, where he flew as a [[United States Air Force]] [[fighter pilot]] in the [[McDonnell Douglas F-4 Phantom II|F-4D Phantom II]]. Following his assignment at RAF Lakenheath, he was reassigned to the [[428th Fighter Squadron|428th Tactical Fighter Squadron]] of the [[474th Tactical Fighter Wing]] at [[Nellis AFB]], Nevada, again flying the [[F-4 Phantom II|F-4D]].{{cite web |url=http://jabara.usafalibrary.com/person.asp?id=49 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2016-07-24 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140514150201/http://jabara.usafalibrary.com/person.asp?id=49 |archivedate=2014-05-14 |df= }}{{cite news |title=Chesley B. Sullenberger III |publisher=AccessInterviews |date=January 16, 2009 |url=http://www.accessinterviews.com/interviews/subject/chesley-b-sullenberger-iii/5911 |accessdate=January 16, 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090124125002/http://accessinterviews.com/interviews/subject/chesley-b-sullenberger-iii/5911 |archivedate=January 24, 2009}} He advanced to become a flight leader and a training officer, and attained the rank of [[Captain (United States uniformed services)#U.S. Army, U.S. Air Force, and U.S. Marine Corps|captain]],{{cite news |last=Altman |first=Alex |title=Two-Minute Bio: Chesley Burnett Sullenberger III |work=[[Time (magazine)|Time]] |date =January 16, 2009 |url=http://www.time.com/time/nation/article/0,8599,1872247,00.html |accessdate=January 16, 2009}} with experience in [[Europe]], [[Pacific Ocean|the Pacific]], and at [[Nellis Air Force Base]], as well as operating as Blue Force Mission Commander in [[Red Flag (USAF)|Red Flag Exercises]]. While in the Air Force, he was a member of an aircraft accident investigation board. ==Civil aviation career== Sullenberger was employed by [[US Airways]] and its predecessor airlines from 1980 until 2010.{{cite news|accessdate=January 17, 2009 |url=http://www3.signonsandiego.com/stories/2009/jan/16/bn16pilot115554-pilot-background-friend/?zIndex=38429|title=US Airways pilot a mix of modesty and professionalism, says Coronado friend|first=Debbi |last=Baker|work= Union-Tribune |location=San Diego, CA|date=January 16, 2009}}{{cite press release| title = US Airways flight 1549: Airline releases crew information |publisher = [[US Airways]]|date =January 16, 2009 | url = http://www.usairways.com/awa/Content/en-US/information/home.html |accessdate =January 17, 2009}} ([[Pacific Southwest Airlines]] was acquired by US Air, later US Airways, in 1988.) He holds an [[Airline Transport Pilot Certificate]] for single and multi-engine airplanes, and a [[Commercial Pilot Certificate]] rating in [[Glider (sailplane)|gliders]], as well as a [[flight instructor]] certificate for airplanes (single, multi-engine, and instrument), and gliders.{{cite web| url = https://amsrvs.registry.faa.gov/airmeninquiry/| title = FAA Airman record for Chesley Burnett Sullenberger III| accessdate = December 18, 2015| author = Federal Aviation Administration}} In total, he has more than 40 years and 20,000 hours of flying experience. In 2007, he became the founder and CEO of Safety Reliability Methods, Inc. (SRM), a firm providing strategic and tactical guidance to enhance organizational safety, performance, and reliability.[http://safetyreliability.com/about-us.html "About Us"]. Safety Reliability Methods, Inc. Retrieved May 22, 2014. He has also been involved in a number of accident investigations conducted by the USAF and the [[National Transportation Safety Board]] (NTSB), such as [[Pacific Southwest Airlines Flight 1771]] and [[USAir Flight 1493]].{{Cite web|url=http://www.airspacemag.com/flight-today/Sullys-Tale.html |title=Sullyâs Tale |publisher=Air & Space magazine |accessdate=February 23, 2009}} He served as an instructor, [[Air Line Pilots Association]] Local Air Safety Chairman, accident investigator, and national technical committee member.{{cite news| title = Profile: Captain Chesley Sullenberger| publisher = [[BBC News]]| date =January 16, 2009 |url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/americas/7832642.stm| accessdate =January 16, 2009}}{{cite news |title=Captainâs skill saved lives of everyone |work=[[The Herald (Glasgow)]] |date=January 16, 2009 |url=http://www.theherald.co.uk/news/other/display.var.2482142.0.Captains_skill_saved_lives_of_everyone.php |accessdate=January 16, 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090122212643/http://www.theherald.co.uk/news/other/display.var.2482142.0.Captains_skill_saved_lives_of_everyone.php |archivedate=January 22, 2009 |df= }} His safety work for ALPA led to the development of a [[Federal Aviation Administration]] Advisory Circular. He was instrumental in developing and implementing the [[Crew Resource Management]] course that is used by US Airways, and he has taught the course to hundreds of airline crew members.Wilson, Reid (October 1, 2009). [http://thehill.com/homenews/campaign/61179-gop-recruited-hero-captain-sully-for-2010-congress-run- "GOP tried to recruit hero pilot 'Sully' for 2010 Congress bid"]. [[The Hill (newspaper)|The Hill]] Working with [[NASA]] scientists, he coauthored a paper on error-inducing contexts in aviation. He was an air accident investigator for an NTSB inquiry into a major accident at [[Los Angeles International Airport]], which "led to improved airline procedures and training for emergency evacuations of aircraft". Sullenberger has also been studying the [[psychology]] behind keeping an airline crew functioning during a crisis.Martin L, Davison J, Orasanu O, et al. Identifying error-inducing contexts in aviation. Paper presented at: SAE World Aviation Conference; October 19 â21, 1999; San Francisco, CA Sullenberger was active with his [[trade union|union]], serving as chairman of a safety committee within the Air Line Pilots Association.[http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/americas/7832642.stm "Profile: Chesley Sullenberger, 'hero of the Hudson' "]. BBC News. January 16, 2009 He was a featured speaker for two panels: one on aviation and one on patient safety in medicine, at the High Reliability Organizations (HRO) 2007 International Conference in [[Deauville, France]], from May 29 to 31, 2007.{{cite news|title=High Reliability Organizations Deauville Conference 2007 Archive |work=HRO2007 |date=May 31, 2007 |url=http://hro-fires.com/hro2007// |accessdate=February 9, 2009}} {{dead link|date=June 2016|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}} ===Flight 1549=== {{Main article|US Airways Flight 1549}} [[File:Plane crash into Hudson River muchcropped.jpg|thumb|right|US Airways Flight 1549 afloat in the Hudson River]] On January 15, 2009, Sullenberger was the captain of [[US Airways Flight 1549]], an [[Airbus A320]] taking off from [[LaGuardia Airport]] in [[New York City]].{{cite web |url=http://www.flightstats.com/go/FlightStatus/flightStatusByFlight.do?&id=149530485&airlineCode=US&flightNumber=1549|title=Flight Status For US 1549}} Shortly after takeoff, the plane [[Bird strike|struck a large flock of birds]] (Canada geese) and lost power in both engines.{{cite news|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/news/2009/01/15/2009-01-15_us_airways_airplane_crashes_in_hudson_ri.html |title=US Airways airplane crashes on Hudson River - Hero pilot Chesley Sullenberger III saves all aboard|author1=Burke, Kerry |author2=Pete Donohue |author3=Corky Siemaszko |last-author-amp=yes |date=January 16, 2009|work=[[Daily News (New York)]]}} Quickly determining he would be unable to reach any airport,{{cite news|url=http://www.iht.com/articles/2009/01/18/news/plane.1-409908.php |accessdate=January 18, 2009 |title= Dramatic details released on plane crash onto the Hudson|author1=Wald, Matthew L. |author2=Al Baker|date=January 18, 2009|work=International Herald Tribune}} Sullenberger piloted the plane to a [[water landing]] on the [[Hudson River]]. All 155 people on board survived and were rescued by nearby boats.{{cite web |url=http://www.nbcnews.com/id/28678669/ns/us_news-life/t/ny-jet-crash-called-miracle-hudson/#.W2uH1yMrJFQ |title=N.Y. jet crash called 'miracle on the Hudson'|date=January 15, 2009 |publisher=MSNBC}} Sullenberger said later: "It was very quiet as we worked, my copilot Jeff Skiles and I. We were a team. But to have zero thrust coming out of those engines was shockingâthe silence."{{cite news|url=http://www.smh.com.au/news/world/hero-pilot-tells-of-shocking-moment-engines-cut-out/2009/02/04/1233423276808.html|title=Hero pilot tells of 'shocking' moment engines cut out |date=February 4, 2009|newspaper=The Sydney Morning Herald|accessdate=September 29, 2016}} Sullenberger was the last to leave the aircraft, after making sure all passengers and crew had evacuated.''[[60 Minutes]]'', February 8, 2009. [[CBS News]]. Sullenberger, described by friends as "shy and reticent," was noted for his poise and calm during the crisis; New York City Mayor [[Michael Bloomberg]] dubbed him "Captain Cool."{{cite news|url=http://www.nypost.com/seven/02102009/news/regionalnews/key_for_captain_marvel_154415.htm|first=Sally |last=Goldenberg|title=Key for Captain Marvel|work=[[New York Post]] |date=February 10, 2009}} Nonetheless, Sullenberger suffered symptoms of [[PTSD|post-traumatic stress disorder]] in subsequent weeks, including sleeplessness and flashbacks.{{cite journal|author=Hewitt, Bill, Nicole Weisenssee Egan, Diane Herbst, Tiffany McGee and Shermakaye Bass|title=Flight 1549: The Right Stuff|journal=[[People (magazine)|People]] magazine|date=February 23, 2009 |pages=60â66 |url=http://people.com/archive/cover-story-flight-1549-the-right-stuff-vol-71-no-7/ |accessdate=January 11, 2018}} He said that the moments before the ditching were "the worst sickening, pit-of-your-stomach, falling-through-the-floor feeling" that he had ever experienced.{{cite news| title=Worst moments of my life: pilot tells of ditching in Hudson| work = [[Sydney Morning Herald]] |agency=AP|date = February 6, 2009| url = http://www.smh.com.au/news/world/audio-reveals-exactly-what-happened--a-hrefhttpmediasmhcomaurid45888blistenba/2009/02/06/1233423442580.html| accessdate =February 6, 2009}} He also said: "One way of looking at this might be that for 42 years, I've been making small, regular deposits in this bank of experience, education and training. And on January 15, the balance was sufficient so that I could make a very large withdrawal."{{cite journal|first=Bill |last=Newcott|title=Wisdom of the Elders |journal=[[AARP Magazine]] |volume=347|date=MayâJune 2009 |page=52|bibcode=2015Sci...347.1110V}} The National Transportation Safety Board ruled that Sullenberger made the correct decision in landing on the river instead of attempting a return to LaGuardiaDodd, Johnny (September 19, 2016). "After the Miracle", ''[[People (magazine)|People]]'', pp 87-88. because the normal procedures for engine loss are designed for cruising altitudes, not immediately after takeoff. Simulations showed that Flight 1549 could have barely made it back to LaGuardia had that maneuver begun immediately after the bird strike, but this scenario completely neglects the time needed to understand what had happened and assess the situation.Paur, Jason (May 5, 2010). [https://www.wired.com/2010/05/ntsb-makes-recommendations-after-miracle-on-the-hudson-investigation/ "Sullenberger Made the Right Move, Landing in the Hudson"]. ''[[Wired (magazine)|Wired]]''.Yang, Carter (May 4, 2010). [http://www.cbsnews.com/news/ntsb-sully-could-have-made-it-back-to-laguardia/ "NTSB: Sully Could Have Made it Back to LaGuardia"]. CBS News. ===Post-flight accolades and publicity=== [[President of the United States|U.S. President]] [[George W. Bush]] called Sullenberger to thank him for saving the lives of the passengers,{{cite news |title = Bush salutes Hudson River pilot who landed plane| publisher = [[Associated Press]]| date =January 16, 2009 |url =https://www.google.com/hostednews/ap/article/ALeqM5gzMdsFeJ5wmBEPLUTBjxw_VRVFagD95ODEK80| accessdate =January 16, 2009}} as did [[President-elect of the United States|President-elect]] [[Barack Obama]],{{cite news| title = Obama, Sullenberger speak by phone| publisher = [[CNN]]| date = January 16, 2009| url = http://politicalticker.blogs.cnn.com/2009/01/16/obama-sullenberger-speak-by-phone/| accessdate =January 16, 2009}} who also invited him and the crew to join [[Barack Obama 2009 presidential inauguration|the presidential inauguration ceremony]].{{cite news| title = Obama, Sullenberger invitation to inauguration| work= [[The Guardian]] |first=Robert |last=Booth| date = January 19, 2009| url = https://www.theguardian.com/world/2009/jan/19/obama-honours-martin-luther-king |accessdate =January 19, 2009}} On January 16, 2009, the [[United States Senate]] passed a resolution recognizing and honoring Sullenberger, Skiles, the cabin crew, the passengers, and the [[first responders]] involved in Flight 1549's emergency landing.{{cite web| title = Text of S.Res.17 Recognizing and honoring Captain Chesley `Sully' Sullenberger III, his copilot Jeffrey Skiles, the crewmembers of U.S. Airways Flight 1549, and the first responders, ferry operators |publisher = Library of Congress| date =January 16, 2009 |url=http://www.thomas.gov/cgi-bin/query/z?c111:S.+Res.+17:|accessdate =January 31, 2009}} The [[United States House of Representatives]] passed a similar resolution on January 26, 2009.{{cite web| title = Text of H.Res.84 Honoring the heroic actions of the pilot, crew, and rescuers of US Airways Flight 1549| publisher = Library of Congress| date =January 26, 2009 | url = http://thomas.loc.gov/cgi-bin/query/z?c111:H.RES.84.ATH:| accessdate =January 31, 2009}} Sullenberger attended the presidential inauguration on January 20, 2009, where he and his wife met President Obama. On January 22, 2009, he and the rest of the crew of Flight 1549 were awarded a Masters Medal by the [[Guild of Air Pilots and Air Navigators]].{{cite web|url=http://www.gapan.org/news/Masters%20Medal%20%20Press%20Release.pdf |title=US Airways Flight 1549 Crew receive prestigious Guild of Air Pilots and Air Navigators Award |publisher=GAPAN |accessdate=January 25, 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090226022800/http://www.gapan.org/news/Masters%20Medal%20%20Press%20Release.pdf |archivedate=February 26, 2009}} A ceremony for Sullenberger was held on January 24, 2009 in Sullenberger's hometown of [[Danville, California]], where he was presented with awards including Danville's "Key to the Town",{{cite news| title = Hero pilot's homecoming| work = [[The Guardian]]|first=Ewen |last=MacAskill| date = January 26, 2009| url = https://www.theguardian.com/world/2009/jan/26/chesley-sullenberger-homecoming| accessdate =January 29, 2009}} and was named an honorary Danville [[police officer]].{{cite news| title = "Just doing my job" says hero pilot Chesley Sullenberger| publisher = [[The Times]]|first=Philippe |last=Naughton| date = January 25, 2009| url = http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/world/us_and_americas/article5583941.ece| accessdate =January 29, 2009 | location=London}} [[San Ramon Valley Fire Protection District]] Chief Richard Price presented Captain Sullenberger with his district's highest award, the Medal of Valor,{{cite news |title = Pilot 'Sully' Sullenberger gets hero's welcome| work = Oakland Tribune| date = January 24, 2009| url = http://www.insidebayarea.com/oaklandtribune/ci_11545863| accessdate =January 30, 2009}} which has been given only a few times in the district's history.{{cite news| title = Calif. Fire Dept. Awards Sullenberger Medal of Valor| work = Fire Chief News| date = January 28, 2009| url = http://firechief.com/news/san_ramon_sullenberger_0128/|accessdate =January 30, 2009}} Sullenberger, Skiles, and Flight 1549's cabin crew, Doreen Welsh, Sheila Dail and Donna Dent, were honored with a standing ovation during the [[Super Bowl XLIII]] pre-game ceremony on February 1, 2009.{{cite news| title = Super ovation for 'Sully', US Airways crew| publisher = [[NBC Sports]] |agency=Associated Press| date = February 1, 2009| url = http://nbcsports.msnbc.com/id/28967586/| accessdate =February 1, 2009}} Sullenberger was awarded with honorary lifetime membership in The [[Seaplane]] Pilot's Association.{{cite news| title = 1549's Sullenberger Becomes Honorary Policeman And Seaplane Society Member| publisher = AVweb| date = January 24, 2009| url = http://www.avweb.com/avwebflash/news/SullenbergerEarnsAccolades_199650-1.html?CMP=OTC-RSS| accessdate =January 29, 2009}}{{cite news|title=SPA and Jack Brown's Seaplane Base Honor Heroic Water Landing |publisher=Seaplane Pilot's Association |date=January 19, 2009 |url=https://www.seaplanes.org/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=617&Itemid=46 |accessdate=January 29, 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160308025624/http://seaplanes.org/index.php?id=617&itemid=46&option=com_content&task=view |archivedate=March 8, 2016}} In 2009, Sullenberger was awarded the Founders' Medal by [[The Air League]].{{cite web |url=http://www.airleague.co.uk/toServlet.jsp?servlet=servlet/SubpageServlet&subsiteId=&pageId=9&subpageId=26&env=1&view=1 |title=The Foundersâ Medal |publisher=The Air League |accessdate=February 7, 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20040112185124/http://www.airleague.co.uk/toServlet.jsp?servlet=servlet%2FSubpageServlet&subsiteId=&pageId=9&subpageId=26&env=1&view=1 |archivedate=January 12, 2004 |df= }} Admirers of Sullenberger also started a [[Facebook]] fan site that, as of late February 2009, had half a million members. A library book, ''Just Culture: Balancing Safety and Accountability'' was in Sullenberger's luggage left behind in the cockpit. When Sullenberger notified the library that the water-damaged book had been recovered, it made a point of waiving any late fees. Bloomberg presented Sullenberger with a new copy along with the [[keys to the city|Key to the City of New York]].{{cite news|work=[[San Jose Mercury News]]|url=http://www.mercurynews.com/breakingnews/ci_11611495|title=Fresno library lets Danville pilot's late fees fly|date=February 2, 2009}}{{cite news |accessdate=July 26, 2009 |url=http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/28984884/|publisher=MSNBC |agency=Associated Press|title=Library lets late fees fly for Hudson pilot; A book checked out to Chesley Sullenberger was left in the cargo hold|date= February 2, 2009}}{{cite news| title = NY mayor hails 'hero' crash pilot| publisher = [[BBC News]]| date = January 16, 2009|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/americas/7834034.stm| accessdate =January 16, 2009}} Sullenberger threw out the [[First Pitch|first pitch]] of the 2009 [[Major League Baseball]] season for the [[San Francisco Giants]]. His Giants' jersey was inscribed with the name "Sully" and the number 155—a reference to the 155 people aboard the plane.{{cite web|url=http://www.mercurynews.com/peninsula/ci_12095405|title=Mountain View school reunion at Giants' opener|last=Reid |first=John|date=April 7, 2009|work=Mercury News|accessdate=April 14, 2009}} On June 6, 2009, Sullenberger returned to his childhood hometown of Denison, Texas, to participate in the town's [[D-Day]] celebration, and to give the commencement address for his alma mater, [[Denison High School]], marking the 40th anniversary of his own graduation from the school.{{cite news|title=Sullenberger in Denison to mark D-Day, commencement|work=[[The Herald Democrat]]|date=June 5, 2009}} Sullenberger also made an appearance in [[St. Louis, Missouri]] on July 14, 2009, to participate in the Red Carpet All-Star Parade before the [[2009 Major League Baseball All-Star Game]]. {{Wikinews2|US Airways jet recovered from Hudson River|"Miracle on the Hudson" pilot retires}} On February 24, 2009, Sullenberger testified before the U.S. House of Representatives's Subcommittee on Aviation of the Committee on Transportation & Infrastructure that his salary had been cut by 40 percent, and that his pension, like most airline pensions, was terminated and replaced by a [[PBGC]] guarantee worth only pennies on the dollar.[http://www.gpo.gov/fdsys/pkg/CHRG-111hhrg47866/pdf/CHRG-111hhrg47866.pdf ''US Airways Flight 1549 Accident'', Hearing]. February 24, 2009. U.S. House, Subcommittee on Aviation, Committee on Transportation and Infrastructure. Washington: Government Printing Office, 2009. He cautioned that airlines were "under pressure to hire people with less experience. Their salaries are so low that people with greater experience will not take those jobs. We have some carriers that have hired some pilots with only a few hundred hours of experience. ... Thereâs simply no substitute for experience in terms of aviation safety."{{cite web|url=http://www.syracuse.com/news/index.ssf/2010/03/miracle_on_the_hudson_pilot_ch.html|title='Miracle on the Hudson' pilot Chesley Sullenberger retires|work=syracuse.com}} Sullenberger also mentioned his pay cut in an October 13, 2009 appearance on ''[[The Daily Show]]''. In 2009, and again in 2015, Sullenberger filmed a TV commercial as a spokesman for [[St. Jude Children's Research Hospital]].[http://www.stjude.org/stjude/v/index.jsp?vgnextoid=0e32cc9e0a9c3210VgnVCM1000001e0215acRCRD&vgnextchannel=5f24598943c8d110VgnVCM1000001e0215acRCRD&SearchUrl=search_results.jsp&QueryText=Sullenberger "A hero among heroes"], [[St. Jude Children's Research Hospital]], accessed December 24, 2010. ==Retirement and subsequent career== [[File:Sullenberger Sydney.JPG|thumb|Sullenberger at the LIONS World Convention 2010 in Sydney]] After 30 years with US Airways and its predecessor, Sullenberger retired in 2010. His final flight was US Airways Flight 1167 from Fort Lauderdale, Florida to Charlotte, North Carolina, where he was reunited with his copilot Jeff Skiles and a half dozen of the passengers on Flight 1549. He was also the 2010 [[Tournament of Roses Parade]]'s [[Grand Marshal]].[https://www.google.com/hostednews/ap/article/ALeqM5hyFRaMyNYacAJ3fnMkx-5922G62wD9BPMPB80 Splashdown pilot Sullenberger to lead Rose Parade], ''Associated Press'', November 5, 2009 On November 18, 2011, as part of a fundraising effort, Sullenberger flew to the [[Carolinas Aviation Museum]] in [[Charlotte, North Carolina]], where the aircraft he landed on the Hudson River is on exhibit.{{cite news|url=http://www.charlotteobserver.com/2011/11/18/2786400/sully-reunited-with-miracle-plane.html |title=Sully reunited with 'miracle' plane |last=Washburn |first=Mark |work=[[The Charlotte Observer]] |date=November 19, 2011 |accessdate=November 19, 2011}} {{dead link|date=November 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes}} In December 2010, Sullenberger was appointed an Officer of France's [[Legion of Honour]].[http://www.gettyimages.com/detail/news-photo/airways-capt-chesley-sully-sullenberger-at-the-presentation-news-photo/114425193 "The French Legion Of Honor Presents Chesley Sullenberger With The Officier Award"]. [[Speed (TV channel)|Speed]]. December 17, 2010. With coauthor [[Jeffrey Zaslow]], Sullenberger wrote the 2009 bestselling memoir ''Highest Duty: My Search for What Really Matters''. On December 7, 1995, Sullenberger's father died by suicide by gunshot shortly after being released from the hospital for major surgery. He had been suffering from depression in the face of a long and difficult convalescence ahead of him. He left no note. As a result of this, Sullenberger became a suicide prevention activist, having promoted [[National Suicide Prevention Week]] and [[National Suicide Prevention Lifeline]]. In October 2009, it was reported that the Republican Party had approached Sullenberger about running against Democratic U.S. Representative [[Jerry McNerney]] of [[California's 11th congressional district]] in the [[United States House of Representatives elections in California, 2010|2010 elections]]. Sullenberger's publicist said that Sullenberger had no desire to run for any public office.{{cite news| last = Wilson |first = Reid |title = GOP tried to recruit hero pilot 'Sully' for 2010 Congress bid| work = [[The Hill (newspaper)|''The Hill'']] |date=October 1, 2009| url =http://thehill.com/homenews/campaign/61179-gop-recruited-hero-captain-sully-for-2010-congress-run-| accessdate =October 5, 2009}} ==In popular culture== The 2010 song "[[A Real Hero]]", by French electronica artist College and the band [[Electric Youth (band)|Electric Youth]], is about Captain Sullenberger and the Flight 1549 water landing. Sullenberger appeared as himself in a cameo role in the 2017 film ''[[Daddy's Home 2]]''. Sullenberger's speech in Congress concerning U.S. civil aviation is featured in [[Michael Moore]]'s 2009 documentary ''[[Capitalism: A Love Story]]''.
